EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Haliburton International Foods has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) for the purpose of protecting employees and the surrounding community.  The EAP covers procedures for: 1) evacuating and accounting for visitors and employees, 2) dealing with an ammonia release and other foreseeable emergencies that could occur onsite, 3) notifying external agencies and emergency response personnel, and 4) administering first aid measures for ammonia exposure.  Employees are informed of the elements of the EAP.  In the event of an ammonia release, employees will evacuate or shelter-in-place, depending on the nature of the release, and the facility will contact the refrigeration contractor and the fire department for assistance as necessary.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Process Hazard Analysis studies and Compliance Audits have been performed on the ammonia refrigeration system, and these studies have resulted in action items to improve safety at the facility.  The recommendations mainly consist of formalizing procedures, implementing practices consistent with industry standards, and performing inspections and tests to maintain the integrity of the equipment.  Haliburton International Foods has implemented several of these action items and is moving forward with completing the remaining outstanding recommendations.   In addition, the facility plans to continue providing employees with a safe work environment through continued training on current policies and procedures, and conducting audits to identify deficiencies and make improvements.

°F Freezer Evaporators receive low temperature recirculated liquid from the -20°F Pump Recirculator,  while the +38°F Dock, Engine Room, Produce Coolers 1 & 2, Packaging, and USDA Evaporators receive high temperature recirculated liquid from the +20°F Pump Recirculator.  The Convertible Area Evaporators (AU-8 - AU-10) can receive low temperature or high temperature recirculated liquid depending on the operation. At the Evaporators, ammonia flows through the evaporator coils and is partially boiled as fans blow air over the evaporator coils.  The resulting 'wet return' (liquid/vapor mixture) from the Evaporators returns to the respective vessel.  The -10°F Freezer Evaporators and Convertible Area Evaporators receive hot gas for coil defrost.

The Low Stage Compressors draw low stage suction from the -20°F Pump Recirculator and the High Stage Compressors draw high stage suction from the +20°F Pump Recirculator.  The Swing Compressor can be configured to draw suction from either Recirculator, depending on demand.  High stage discharge flows to the Evaporative Condenser and is routed to the Underfloor Heat Exchanger to warm glycol and to the Freezer and Convertible Evaporators for coil defrost.  All of the Compressors are water-cooled.

The Underfloor Heat Exchanger is a plate and frame heat exchanger which is designed to be used in a separate, closed loop system for under floor heating.  The Underfloor Heat Exchanger receives hot gas from the Compressors.  As hot gas passes through the heat exchanger unit, it is condensed as the glycol absorbs heat from the ammonia.  The resulting liquid drains to the Evaporative Condenser.

At the Evaporative Condenser, air (fans) and water (pumps) are used to condense the high stage discharge from the Compressors into high pressure liquid, which then drains to the High Pressure Receiver to begin the refrigeration cycle again.  The system is also equipped with an Automatic Purger that removes non-condensables, i.e. air, from the syste

o the vessel flashes some of the liquid in the bath of the vessel; as liquid flashes, the remaining liquid in the bath is sub-cooled.  Sub-cooled liquid is sent to the -20°F Pump Recirculator.  Liquid is also pumped to Evaporators AU-11 - AU-25, AU-8 - AU-10 (depending on operation) and the Glycol Chiller Heat Exchanger as high temperature recirculated liquid.  High stage suction is drawn from the top of the vessel by the High Stage Compressors and the Swing Compressor.  The vessel is equipped with a high level mechanical float switch that shuts down the Compressors in the event of a high level situation. Additionally there is a liquid transfer vessel that will transfer excess liquid in the +20°F Pump Recirculator to the High Pressure Receiver in a high level situation.

The -20°F Pump Recirculator receives low temperature recirculated suction from Evaporators AU-1 - AU-7 and AU-8 - AU-10 (depending on the operation) and sub-cooled liquid ammonia from the +20°F Pump Recirculator.  The sub-cooled liquid ammonia feed to the vessel is controlled by a level controller which throttles the motorized valve to maintain operating level in the vessel.  Liquid is also pumped to Evaporators AU-1 - AU-7 and AU-8 - AU-10 (depending on the operation) as low temperature recirculated liquid.  Low stage suction is drawn from the top of the vessel by the Low Stage Compressors and the Swing Compressor.  The vessel is equipped with a high level mechanical float switch that shuts down the Compressors in the event of a high level situation. Additionally there is a liquid transfer line that will activate a solenoid to transfer the excess liquid back to the +20°F Pump Recirculator in a high level situation.

The Evaporators provide refrigeration to the -10°F Freezer (AU-1 - AU-7), Convertible Area (AU-8 - AU-10), Engine Room (AU-11), +38°F Dock (AU-12 & AU-13), Produce Coolers 1 & 2 (AU-14 - AU-19), Packaging (AU-20 - AU-22), USDA (AU-23 - AU-25) and Bowl Packaging (AU-26 - AU-27).  The -10

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Haliburton International Foods is committed to providing a safe environment to its employees and surrounding communities.  This commitment is reflected in the safety and environmental programs that are implemented at the facility.  For example, written procedures have been created for operating the ammonia refrigeration system.  Only trained operators / refrigeration contractor are permitted to perform system operations.  Haliburton International Foods has also developed a robust maintenance program to ensure the equipment is in good operating condition.  All of these programs are geared towards the prevention of an accidental release at the facility.  In addition, these programs incorporate emergency procedures to mitigate the effects of a release if it does occur.  At such an event, emergency coordinators will assess the situation and notify outside responding agencies as necessary.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

Haliburton International Foods is located at 3855 E. Jurupa Street in Ontario, California.  Ammonia is used in the facility's refrigeration system to provide cooling for the processing and storage of frozen food products.  The system uses a maximum of 10,856 pounds of ammonia.  A description of how the process operates is presented below:  

The refrigeration cycle begins with the transfer of liquid ammonia from the Evaporative Condenser to the High Pressure Receiver.  The High Pressure Receiver feeds high pressure liquid ammonia to the +20°F Pump Recirculator.  

The +20°F Pump Recirculator receives high temperature recirculated suction from Evaporators AU-11 - AU-27, AU-8 - AU-10 (depending on the operation) and the Heat Exchangers and high pressure liquid ammonia from the High Pressure Receiver.
